body.p: This study was conducted in compliance with the Transparency In The reporting of Artificial INtelligence – the TITAN guideline[1].

The brain and central nervous system (CNS) cancers are major and increasingly serious global public health problems, especially in the 15-39 age group[2,3]. These cancers, which comprise malignant tumors of the spinal cord, meninges, brain, as well as other parts of the CNS, pose a heavy burden of disease with high morbidity and mortality. CNS cancers vary from cancers in older populations in that they present distinct biological, clinical, and behavioral problems[4].

Zhang et al[5] project future loads and examine trends using data from the Global Burden of Disease (GBD) 2021. This study presents a comprehensive overview of global trends as well as future projections for CNS and brain cancers, underscoring the necessity for sustained improvements in health care and targeted policy interventions to effectively address the management and mitigation of the global burden of these diseases.

Lifestyle, environmental, genetic along with immunological factors are all part of the complex pathogenesis of CNS cancers. Genetic susceptibility and gene mutations are two important factors leading to the risk of CNS cancer, while environmental exposure – particularly ionizing radiation – is another important factor. Studies have consistent indicated that there is a well-established risk factor for brain tumors with ionizing radiation and that cancer survivors who have been treated with radiation therapy are at greater risk of developing secondary CNS malignancies. Lifestyle changes, in particular in high-income countries, may also be a driver of CNS cancer incidence. Although the exact relationship between obesity and CNS cancer is still unknown, metabolic syndrome and obesity have been associated with a variety of malignancies. Oxidative stress, insulin resistance, and chronic low-grade inflammation are some of the ways that obesity may indirectly raise the chance of developing cancer. Changes in diet, especially a greater consumption of foods heavy in fat and sugar, may make these metabolic disturbances worse and raise the risk of CNS malignancies. CNS cancer development can be indirectly influenced by fat accumulation, metabolic dysregulation, and raised risk of chronic disease.

There are a number of limitations to take into account. First, the true burden of CNS cancers may be underestimated due to inadequate cancer registration systems that result in underreporting or inaccurate data. Second, various kinds of CNS cancers, each with its own etiology, prognosis, and response to treatment, are not distinguished in this study. Third, the observed patterns of CNS cancer burden may have been influenced by confounders like population growth or healthcare access, which were not specifically taken into account in this study. In order to better comprehend the global burden of CNS cancers and to help develop more targeted public health policies, future research should concentrate on strengthening etiological investigations, increasing data collecting, and improving the categorization of CNS cancers.
